abstract.text: Convolves a floating-point 32-bit planar image by a 2D kernel.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A pointer to a vImage buffer structure that contains data for the source image.
A pointer to a vImage buffer data structure. You’re responsible for filling out the
, and

fields of this structure, and for allocating a data buffer of the appropriate size. On return, the data buffer this structure points to contains the destination image data. When you no longer need the data buffer, you must deallocate the memory. The size (number of rows and number of columns) of the destination buffer also specifies the size of the region of interest in the source buffer.
A pointer to a temporary buffer. If you pass

, the function allocates the buffer, then deallocates it before returning. Alternatively, you can allocate the buffer yourself, in which case you are responsible for deallocating it when you is no longer need it.
If you want to allocate the buffer yourself, see the Discussion for information on how to determine the minimum size that you must allocate.
The horizontal offset, in pixels, to the upper-left pixel of the region of interest within the source image.
The vertical offset, in pixels, to the upper-left pixel of the region of interest within the source image.
A pointer to the convolution kernel data, which must be a packed array without any padding.
The height of the kernel in pixels. This value must be odd.
The width of the kernel in pixels. This value must be odd.
A background color. If you supply a color, you must also set the
flag, otherwise the function ignores the color.
The options to use when performing the operation. If your code implements its own tiling or its own multithreading, pass
Pass one of the following flags to specify how vImage handles pixel locations beyond the edge of the source image:
, or
; otherwise, one of the error codes in
If you want to allocate the memory for the
parameter yourself, call this function twice, as follows:
To determine the minimum size for the temporary buffer, the first time you call this function pass the

flag. Pass the same values for all other parameters that you intend to use in for the second call. The function returns the required minimum size, which should be a positive value (a negative returned value indicates an error). The
flag prevents the function from performing any processing other than to determine the minimum buffer size.
After you allocate enough space for a buffer of the returned size, call the function a second time, passing a valid pointer in the
parameter. This time, do not pass the
flag.

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
A type for a planar, 32-bits-per-channel, floating-point pixel.
A flag that uses the background color for missing pixels.
A flag that copies the value of the edge pixel in the source to the destination.
A flag that disables vImage internal tiling routines.
A flag that extends the edges of the image infinitely.
The vImage function completed without error.
A flag that uses only the part of the kernel that overlaps the image.
Convolves a floating-point 16-bit-per-channel, 4-channel interleaved image by a 2D kernel, then divides the pixel values by a divisor.
Convolves an 8-bit-per-channel, 4-channel interleaved image by a 2D kernel and divides the pixel values by a divisor.
Convolves a floating-point 32-bit-per-channel, 4-channel interleaved image by a 2D kernel, then divides the pixel values by a divisor.
Convolves a floating-point 16-bit planar image by a 2D kernel.
Convolves an 8-bit planar image by a 2D kernel and divides the pixel values by a divisor.
Convolves a floating-point 32-bit planar image by a 2D kernel.
A type for the number of pixels.
An image buffer that stores an image’s pixel data, dimensions, and row stride.
A type for image errors.
A type for processing options.
Look up type aliases, data types, and constants the vImage library uses.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A single-precision, floating-point value type.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
A 32-bit unsigned integer value type.
